channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline
channel.description: RSS feed for the Mastodon Home timeline

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
@elduvelle @PessoaBrain @kordinglab
To be clear, I really appreciate Mastodon and my experience here. What I particularly love about it is interacting with individuals, most often related to how the brain works (and breaks) with individuals of all types (scientists and non-scientists alike). It's the interaction here that is really special. It's authentic and honest and more often than not, focused on learning from one another. To channel what I know to be the complaints of some others:1) Some individuals aren't just interested in social media for interaction. They have a message to spread and Mastodon is simply not the best platform for "reach". If you want to convince as many people as you can about Covid/Global Warming/etc, Mastodon is not a bad way but it's also not the best way. And it won't ever be the best. There's no algorithm to spread the word, etc. Insofar as we brain researchers want to also be public facing scientific communicators, this is relevant. Similarly, if you want to reach a community beyond, say, neuroscience (URMs, PhD students at large, etc), this is relevant.2) A lot of individuals find the Mastodon community alienating, for a few reasons. For some, when they are engaged in social media, many want to be lighthearted and have fun. That's not the vibe here; rather, the vibe is pretty serious. There are a lot of social norms and a lot of pile on for violating them. If you are naturally on board with those norms, it's no big deal (and I feel this is generally the case for me - it's easy). But if you like to shit post, you may run into some issues. Many people don't want to feel they are walking on eggshells to engage. Similarly, this platform also has a history of not treating certain communities very well, which once again, is alienating.

item.title: MCDuncanLab
item.description: @askennard DpnI digest your PCR to remove template.PPTase vector and if possible digest with a third enzyme to prevent religation of excised MCS.

item.title: Dan Gillmor
item.description: A person I otherwise deeply respect has remained (very) active on the deadbird site, and is even paying for it, because (the person says) it fulfills a professional need that can't be met elsewhere. My friend calls it "a deal with the devil." On that, we agree.I have my share of hypocrisies, and try to manage them carefully. Sticking with a site run by an enemy of journalism and democracy was just too much to stomach.Journalists should leave. Period.

item.title: Christophe Leterrier 🔬
item.description:
🔬First method-focused work from our lab is just out in Cell Reports Methods 🎉
Interested in multicolor SMLM? Check the open-access final version of Karoline Friedl's PhD work, with Sandrine Lévêque-Fort's lab and the Abbelight gang
https://www.cell.com/cell-reports-methods/fulltext/S2667-2375(23)00215-1

item.title: Konrad Kording
item.description: @FroehlichMarcel @NicoleCRust @elduvelle @PessoaBrain I guess I see your arguments against recommenders. But I find that feeds I get that are ordered for my preferences by an algorithm are much better than those that come from people I follow. Simply because I am weird. But it is a huge effect for me. Mastodon is good serious stuff. That I mostly don't care about.Its not even close. If I look at my home here, 90% of posts are just element number 20 of some discussion of a point that is not close to my heart. The experience is just booooring.

item.title: Konrad Kording
item.description: Gait based biomarkers are going to happen. Why am I positive? A good doctor can use them already. What a trained human eye can do an algorithm can learn as well. Progress in that direction is slow but steady. E.g. https://arxiv.org/pdf/2307.16321.pdf

item.title: Albert Cardona
item.description:
James W. Truman featured in the New Yorker. A warm, lovely piece on his career studying insect metamorphosis, from moths to flies and mosquitoes, and the role and impact of hormones on insect development and behaviour—motivated by his latest work mapping the fate of neurons from larva to adult through pupal stages, and addressing an old question: do associative memories persist through metamorphosis?https://www.newyorker.com/science/elements/what-insects-go-through-is-even-weirder-than-we-thoughtThe paper:
“Metamorphosis of memory circuits in Drosophila reveals a strategy for evolving a larval brain” Truman et al. 2023 https://elifesciences.org/articles/80594#neuroscience #entomology #metamorphosis #insects #ecdyzone #Drosophila #moths #mosquitoes #NewYorker

item.title: franco_vazza
item.description: Considering that the volume in a 1000 Mpc distance is dominated by voids, the consensus is that the suppression of the secondary Inverse Compton Cascade reported by many observations (and not limited to Fermi_LAT observations, but also MAGIC, VERITAS, HESS…) is a proof for the existence of a tiny magnetisation of the emptiest regions in the Universe!

item.title: Virgile Andreani
item.description:
"Truthfully, I gave up the piano for two solid months. And I had crying fits at night. I would go to bed at night and it haunted me, it actually haunted me that someone could play the piano so well."
— virtuoso pianist Oscar Peterson on the first time he heard Art TatumWhen impostor syndrome gets me, I always try to remember that even Oscar Peterson came close to quitting because he felt not good enough.The full interview of Peterson: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BFNsywQOW1I#ImpostorSyndrome #Academia

item.title: Nate Himmel
item.description: Latest preprint with @bentonlab@twitter.com studying insect OR evolution: we've found homologs across the entire tree of life! Insect receptors are just a majorly expanded branch of a 4 billion year old protein superfamily...https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.08.30.555482#phylogenetics #alphafold #esm #huggingface #LECA #LUCA #7TMIC #chemosensation #smell #taste #olfaction #insects #evolution #neuroscience

item.title: socneuronerd
item.description: Finally. It is here. 🤓

item.title: Dan Goodman
item.description: I'm currently developing a new course "Neuroscience for machine learners" that I hope to be able to make publicly available, and I'd love to hear what you think should be in it.It's aimed at people with a machine learning background to learn a bit about neuroscience. My thinking is that neuroscience and ML have had fruitful links in the past, and may again in the future (although right now they're drifting apart). This course is designed to give students the background they'd need to be able to discover, understand and make use of new opportunities arising from neuroscience (if they do). I'm not trying to tell them only about the bits of neuroscience that we already think are applicable to ML, but to give them enough background to read and understand enough neuroscience to allow them to make new discoveries about what might be applicable to ML. The constraint is that it can't just be an intro to neuro course I think, because I'm not sure how compelling that would be to students with an ML focus. The course is 10 weeks and will have quite a practical focus, with most of the attention on weekly coding based exploratory group work rather than lectures. (Similar to @neuromatch Academy.)I have thoughts about what should be on this course, but I'd love to know what you all think would be most relevant.#neuroscience #compneuro #machinelearning #ai
